Localized Prostate Cancer_1:
Description 1:
A 62-year-old male patient, with a history of benign prostatic hyperplasia, was referred for further evaluation due to an elevated total prostate-specific antigen (PSA) level. His digital rectal examination revealed a palpable nodule in the left lobe of the prostate. Transrectal ultrasound-guided biopsy was performed, and the histopathology report indicated the presence of localized prostate cancer, with 70% of the cores showing malignancy. The patient is asymptomatic and reports no urinary or sexual dysfunction. His pain level is zero, and he has been leading a generally healthy lifestyle. Given the diagnostic findings, the total number and percentage of positive cores will be crucial in determining the appropriate management strategy for the localized prostate cancer.
Localized Prostate Cancer_2:
Description 2:
A 55-year-old male patient, without a significant medical history, presented with persistently elevated prostate-specific antigen (PSA) levels during routine screening. He has no specific symptoms related to the genitourinary system and reports a pain level of zero. A transrectal ultrasound-guided biopsy of the prostate was performed, and the histopathology results revealed localized prostate cancer. Notably, 90% of the cores obtained from the biopsy specimen showed malignancy. The patient leads an active lifestyle and has no urinary or sexual dysfunction. The total number and percentage of positive cores will play a crucial role in determining the optimal management approach for the localized prostate cancer in this case.
Localized Prostate Cancer_3:
Description 3:
In a 68-year-old male patient with a history of prostatitis, the recent monitoring of prostate-specific antigen (PSA) levels has shown a steady increase. The patient denies specific genitourinary symptoms and reports a pain level of zero. A digital rectal examination disclosed a palpable nodule in the right lobe of the prostate. Subsequent transrectal ultrasound-guided biopsy confirmed localized prostate cancer, with 50% of the cores demonstrating malignancy. The patient's medical history is notable for prostatitis, but he has been managing it effectively with previous treatments. He leads a healthy lifestyle and has no urinary or sexual dysfunction. The total number and percentage of positive cores will be essential in guiding the management of the localized prostate cancer identified in this patient.
